title: Classifications
hypotheses:
<Figure
          src="images/causality/causal_hypothesis.png"
          alt="Hypothesis"
          caption="The possible causalities of the biomarkers"
          n={1}
        />

title: GlialCells
hypotheses:
It is possible to make a model of MEG signal / features based on
                tau and Aβ that takes into account their interactions with one
                another and with glial cells. As it is possible to predict the
                AD progression based on MEG features it would help understand
                glial cells role in AD progression.

title: HUBS
hypotheses:
The vulnerability of hub regions in AD may be due to their high connectivity, which makes them more susceptible to the spread of pathological proteins and the propagation of neurodegenerative processes.
We could try to find the correlation between the connectivity of the region and the vulnerability to AD.

We could make a model to predict the progression of AD based on the
        previous model of signal but adding the connectivity of the regions.

This finding could explain why previous hypersynchronization phenomena
        were found at several frequency bands.

There is a correlation between the metabolic demands of the region and
        the presence of Aβ plaques.

title: Amyloid Beta (AB)
hypotheses:
Unexpected results based on our model. Can we reproduce
                        that ?

Aβ plaques concentration is associated with an increased
                frequency of epileptiform activity in AD patients.

In AD patients, a higher density of Aβ plaques will correlate
                with a flatter PSD slope, particularly in frontal and temporal
                regions, due to decreased perisomatic GABAergic inhibition and
                increased neuronal hyperactivity in these areas.

In brain regions with both Aβ and tau pathology, the effect on
                PSD slope will depend on the relative densities of Aβ versus
                tau: Aβ-dominant regions will have a flatter slope, while
                tau-dominant regions will exhibit a steeper slope.

title: RetrogenesisModel
hypotheses: Myelination is a protector against tau assimilation.

title: TauSpread
hypotheses:
There is a correlation between activity and tau spread
                    potentially explaining the AB cascade.

title: Tau
hypotheses:
Regions with High Tau Burden Show Altered Aperiodic Slopes,
                Reflecting an Imbalance in Excitatory-Inhibitory Activity

Not the expected results based on the model can we reproduce
                    that ?

Soluble tau is a better predictor of cognitive decline than
                    NFTs.

Regions with high tau pathology in AD patients will show a
                steeper PSD slope due to tau's impact on excitatory
                neurons, resulting in reduced high-frequency power and an
                increased relative contribution of low-frequency activity.

title: Hyperexcitability
hypotheses:
Hypersynchrony observed in AD is a direct result of Aβ-induced
                overactivation of excitatory neurons due to disrupted inhibitory
                (GABAergic) control, rather than a compensatory mechanism.
                Supported by{" "}
                <CitationCard citations={[bibtex.maestu2021neuronal]}>
                    the loss of GABAergic transmission, could induce
                    hyperactivity, increasing the probability of local
                    synchronization of brain oscillatory activity
                </CitationCard>

If hypersynchrony is driven by Aβ pathology, then directional
                connectivity from regions with higher Aβ load to regions with
                lower Aβ load should show causal hypersynchrony.

title: Entorhinal
hypotheses:
There is a correlation between the metabolic rate of the region
                (due to high dendritic complexity, long unmyelinated axons, high
                degrees of plasticity, and unique gene expression signature
                related to tau homeostasis) and tau burden.

title: Assymetric
hypotheses:
Tau and/or Amyloid-Beta Burden in Posterior Hubs Correlates with
        Disrupted Posterior-to-Anterior Information Flow in the Beta Band

Tau Pathology in the Hippocampi Correlates with Theta Band Connectivity
        and Information Flow to Anterior Regions. Although the study did not
        find significant group differences in the theta band, it may be that tau
        deposition specifically affects theta flow involving the hippocampi,
        which could be overlooked in the general analysis.

title: Frequencies
hypotheses:
Increased Tau Accumulation Leads to Decreased High-Frequency Power
        (Alpha/Beta) in Excitatory-Dominated Regions

High Tau Levels Correlate with Increased Low-Frequency Power
        (Delta/Theta) as a Result of Compensatory Inhibitory Activity

The Ratio of Low- to High-Frequency Power Increases with Tau Load,
        Indicating Shifts Toward Slower Rhythms in Tau-Rich Regions

title: NMM
hypotheses:
Using NMM we can show that δ-θ power increase is due to
          changes in the slope by varying the neural gain without changing the
          time constant or neural populations.

The increased excitatory neural gains and reduced inhibitory neural
          gains in AD patients could be a compensatory mechanism to the
          increased neuronal time-constants.

title: Periodic
StructuralConnectivity
hypotheses:
No correlation exist between the decrease in slow-wave activity
                (δ-θ) and FA accounting for AB as covariate (indeed
                AB will have an effect on slow band rythm). Supporting the idea
                that the decrease in slow-wave activity is not related to real
                structural connectivity changes but rather the change in the
                slope.
